text:
Draft in Lake Mills, WI. Dark brown color with light tan head. Roasted coffee aroma. Roasted coffee flavor. Much better that most coffee brews. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

How crazy is it to find an 8-year-old bottle of Devil Over a Barrel in the back of the beer cellar? (Bottled on 09APR08) Not a lot of pop when removing the cap (duh!) but still a respectable head when poured (though it dissipated quickly). Coffee and vanilla are both very pronounced in the aroma initially. After sitting for a bit, the aroma also has charred wood and dark chocolate. A little flat carbonation but body still has respectable weight and the texture is silky smooth. Nicely sweet over the tongue and on the finish. Will have to get a new bottle to accurately update the rating because, really, normal people arent going to let this intentionally sit for 8 years.

Pours pitch black with a small brown head. Smells of coffee and vanilla. Taste is coffee bitterness, hints of chocolate, rounded sweetness. Full-bodied with a smooth texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Tyranena Devil Over A Barrel finishes with a lingering sweetness.

Bottle thanks to motortoddhead. Dark brown pour with a small ring of head. Aroma is ultra fresh coffee beans, toasted oak, light bourbon, light coconut, and light chocolate. Tastes like a nice mix of bourbon and coffee beans. Very oaky, lots of vanilla, some light dusty cocoa, some light maple too. Smooth and little creamy. Medium to full body. Very good BB imperial porter.

Dark beer with reddish hues when held against the light. Very little of a brown wisp for a head. Enticing aroma of coffee, bourbon and vanilla. None of the added flavors here overpower this beer. Very well balanced roasted grains, bitter coffee, vanilla, oak and bourbon alcohol with a long bitter finish. Another well crafted beer from Tyranena.

Dark reddish-brown pour with light tan head. Aroma is coffee. Taste is coffee, creamy, oatmeal, light bourbon. What a tasty beer. I am so glad it is available in my area now. great mouth feel. Nice coffee flavor.

12 ounce bottle from AWISLguy. Pours a red-brown with a thin fizzy tan head. Good head retention. Aroma of roasted malt, wood, coffee, vanilla, whiskey, dark fruit. Medium bodied, mild lingering roast.
Bottle. Pours charcoal black with no head. Lots of coffee and a bit of dark chocolate in the nose. Taste is the same with a nice "chewiness" from the oatmeal. Thick, rich and great on a cold night.
Creamy body of roasted caramel and coffee malt flavors, gaining depth from subtle bourbon underneath. Smooth, long finish, with subtle hops lingering and adding complexity to the rich malt.
bottle to snifter. pour is black and nearly flat. nose is grainy and boozy. some chocolate. Taste is lightly spicy and vanilla. pretty tasty.

At tall Matts house with Matt, Matt, garrett, and respective chicks. Pour dark brown maroon. Aroma bourbon, oatmeal roasted stout. Taste is some whiskey flavor, thin, kinda sticky. Pretty good. Def a porter.
Flaske, 355 ml. Mørk brunsort, lavt ret lyst beige skum. Duft af fløde-kaffe. Til den bitter-søde side. Fyldig, fløjl. Alkohol. Laaang eftersmag.
Bottle thanks to Seth. Pours a clear amber with no head. The aroma is strong roast, coffee bean, and booze. Thin mouthfeel with nice roast, dark chocolate, light heat, wood, sweet finish. Very good.

> Green coffee and bourbon, maple, brown sugar breakfast stout
[ Bottle ][ 12oz ][ motorheadtodd ][ Trade ][ Hotel Room Garbage Glass ][ 8.16.14 ]
>> Thank you Todd! Black pour, great tan foam with good retention. Nose begins with green jalapeños, spicy green coffee. Taste is dusty dark chocolate, silkier chocolate, a good amount of brown sugar and maple, warming bourbon. Has a bourbon maple pancake type taste with sweetened coffee. A breakfast stout for sure. Really nice.
Pours black like oil with just a small amount of khaki colored head. Coffee, bourbon, oak, and chocolate on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with cocoa and coffee, very smooth.
really coffee flavored and bitter finish slightly chocolately and easy to drink. smells chocaoltey had this opne at bad apple on a draft pout. balck in color witha tan head.

Bottle as a trade extra from I forget who. Thanks! Pours dark brown to black with some light showing through on the pour but not in the glass, with a small khaki brown head. Huge earthy spicy coffee aroma, sweet lactose and chocolate. Flavor is a rush vanilla coffee combo, very smooth and decadent, without the harsh coffee spice. Wow this is very smooth. Not much bourbon, just a hint of oakiness. Medium bodied and very silky, low plus carbonation, lasting chocolate coffee finish on the tongue. Very nice.
Bottle - Pours dark brown/black w/ tan head. Hints of vanilla, oak, oatmeal, and bourbon in the nose. Rich chocolate flavor and a nice oatmeal feel on the palate. Very smooth overall!!!

12 oz bottle shared by huhzubendah, thanks Matt. Pours a clear dark caramel brown. Nearly headless, just a tiny wisp appears when swirled. Aroma leapt out of the bottle into my nose. Chocolate malt, sweet malts, coffee, and the caramelly complexity of bourbon. Flavor is porter roastiness, chocolate, caramel, nutty coffee and a smooth bourbon finish. This tastes bigger than 8%, nicely done. Sweet caramel aftertaste, thin to medium mouthfeel. Solid.

Overall mine was flat, not a good start. Decent flavor albeit it a bit hot. Finish was thin and mostly just alcohol. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark red/brown pour. Nose is dark fruits, chocolate, bourbon. Taste is chocolate, barrel, dark fruits. Medium mouthfeel.

Bottle from Discount Liquors in Milwaukee. 

Served alongside the standard version.

Similar appearance to the non barrel-aged version. Dark brown with a quarter inch of beige cap that leaves sparse lacing. Nice aroma, with everything present in the original, not overpowered by bourbon. A touch of oak and light, but present bourbon. Gentle sweetness. Sweet, powerful bourbon dancing with fresh, bitter coffee beans. Delightful. Well done.

4 pack $8.49 - great price for such a high quality beer

12 oz bottle thanks to Bacterial. Dark pour with brown head that shows up just for a moment before dissipating. Prominent coffee in the aroma that takes center stage. Chocolate falls into line in the mouth, along with artificial vanilla and residual sweetness. Full body, syrupy, thick texture, above average carbonation. Overall: tasty brew!

12 ounce bottle. Thanks Al. Pours black with a decent tan head. Aroma of coffee, malt, and chocolate. Taste is coffee, roasted malt, dark chocolate, vanilla, and some bourbon. Very well balanced. Will look for this one again!

Exceptional BA Imperial Porter. Has a creamy mouthfeel - stays light whilst pouring almost as a dessert style beer. Aroma is vanilla bean and mocha. An outstanding beer with chewy oats and a warm bourbon barrel afterglow. This is excellent, from the opening of the bottle to the last sip.

This puppy is a full dessert. Thick black pour from draft at farmhouse in Evanston. Huge toffee and Carmel aroma. Scotch smell too. Taste is massive. Coffee, chocolate, toffee and milky. Love this one. Haven't liked many other from this brewery. Score

Pre-DLD bottle share at Hampton Inn. Pour is deep brown with a small beige head. Aroma and flavor of bakers chocolate, roasted malt, coffee grounds, and slight bourbon warmth. Finish is bourbon and chocolate malt.
Pours dark with a whisp of tan head. Aroma of black coffee, vanilla beans, and roast. Taste of fresh brewed coffee, vanilla, oatmeal, and just the right amount of barrel. Good brew.

Bottle shared thanks to beerman6686. Nice to break up the barleywines with this one. Pours a dark brown with a slight tan head. Aroma is huge black coffee. None of that green pepper stuff. Taste is slightly sweet up front but finishes on the dry side and bitter. Not a ton of barrel spirits come past the coffee even with the 60% blend.

Great smelling beer with a wonderful coffee, chocolate and slight bourbon taste. Only complaint is that it poured completely flat and gave it a weird mouthfeel. Otherwise great beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
draft. An imperial porter that really retains its coffee characterl despite the barrel aging.

Dark brown body spews handsome tan head. Decadent chocolate & roasty aroma bleeds onto the palate. Barrels massage the overall profile just enough to introduce themselves without stealing the spotlight. Creamy oatmeal body pairs nicely. 

Quite impressive overall. Dare I say I prefer this to Breakfast Stout?!

Aroma of coffee and a little smoke. Small dark tan head. Great complexity of chocolate coffee and bourbon.
Medium mouthfeel. 
Amazing beer.
Bottle. Deep brown with a tan ring. Vanilla, oatmeal, roasted malt, bourbon and oak. Taste is malty sweet with an alcohol aftertaste. Body is heavier with an oily feel

Poured from a bottle. I wish they would go to pop top caps. Dark medium viscosity body. Huge coffee aroma. I thought the taste was a little mild, but very drinkable. Then I realized it was a porter not a stout so the heavy roasted sweetness missing is normal. Pretty good. Could really l easily drink a lot of this.

Bottle from Discount in Milwaukee served at fridge temperature - very excited to see this one was re-released after 4-5 years! Pours inky black with a bit of a foamy tan head leaving spots of lace. Aroma has all bakers chocolate, coffee and vanilla. Lovely! Rich and decadent. Taste is of sweet cocoa, bitter espresso, bakers chocolate, some espresso and some vanilla. Medium to full bodied and lovely in the choco/coffee/vanilla blend (2 parts and 2 parts to 1). Finishes with some length, and slightly more sweet than bitter, with the chocolate/vanilla slightly passing the bakers chocolate & espresso components. This is very nice! As a note, a cellar temp version did not impress quite as much. Tyranena SO does porters!! This one is a great option to cellar for a while, but not sure Ill be able to not drink what is left; going to need to find another 4 pack ....

36cl, as Tyranena Brewers Gone Wild! Devil Over a Barrel, exclusive American brew, with coffee, thx alot to Koen for bringing this over!, complex Porter, malty/roasted and slightly alcoholic/sweet/woody, yet not too heavy, very balanced, cloudy, small head, very good brew

The appearance is of a typical imperial porter or stout - dark and inky with a very slight foam where the top of the pour meets the glass. The aroma has clear coffee notes as well as whiffs of raisin, nut and caramel. The taste is very nice, following on the same sensations of the aroma (coffee, caramel, a toasted nutty flavor and a hint of vanilla) and is very nice. The coffee especially is present at the back of the tongue on the finish of a sip. Mouth-feel/palate is again very typical of a good imperial porter, not overly thick, but it has a lot more texture than a lighter beer. This is a very nice beer, which Im thankful a friend brought back from WI for me to enjoy here in California.
12 oz bottle. Nice coffee and mocha aroma. Taste is brownies with a touch of espresso. Bourbon notes are very subtitle. Balanced and easy to drink. Might be the only bourbon stout I could pound.

Thin black pour with some tan head. Lots of tan lacing. Huge coffee nose with some bourbon undertones. Mouthfeel is a bit on the thin side, but fine for a porter (maybe thin for an imperial porter?). Tons of flavor. Coffee, toffee, vanilla and bourbon. Yum.
Beautiful aroma of chocolate and oatmeal and coffee. Taste is similar, a slight sweet, bitter finish.

Black pour, medium tan head
Aroma is coffee, dark and bakers chocolate and oats. Light Oakley vanilla.
Flavour is coffee right off the bat. Chocolate covered espresso beans. 
Oily oat mouthfeel. Roasted malt, vanilla, woody hop bitterness in finish.
Very little bourbon for me.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Brownish black pour with huge fluffy tan head. Nose is fantastic! Huge fresh, ashy/smokey coffee, brown sugar and bourbon with light vanilla. Flavor is more fresh smokey coffee, light bourbon, roasted malt, light vanilla sweetness. Silky smooth oat character with lingering light, sweet bourbon and coffee. All flavors well-melded. Dig the fact that this was not 100% barrel-aged. Made flavors more nuanced and appreciable.
Bottle. Dark pour with a small head. Awesome coffee and subtle bourbon in this, plus some roast malt. This is fantastic.

12oz bottle pours a dark chocolate brown with a slight reddish hue, tan head and small lacing. Aromas of chocolate, vanilla, coffee, roastyness, and bread. Flavor is slight bitter with a sweet finish. Smooth mouth feel. Vanilla chocolate milk beer. Excellent.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2014 Bottle. Pours clear deep reddish mahogany, medium tan head, dissipates fairly quickly with good lacing. Aroma is coffee, bourbon, roasted malt. Flavor follows, mellow and medium sweet, light bitter, bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, espresso. Medium light body. Tasty as hell.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2014 Pours dark brown black. The tail of a brown head. Aroma Booms with coffee and chocolate. Flavor matches the absurdly luxurious coffee and chocolate. Velvety bourbon and vanilla swirl into the mix. Voluptuous body. Sexy as hell.

12oz bottle. Black pour with a thin khaki head and sticky lacing. nice aroma of dark bakers chocolate, coffee and roasted malts. coffee is potent in this one. taste is of bitter dark chocolate, coffee, roasted malts very bitter and coffee like brew. This is missing the bourbon notes and has a very bitter dark roasted dry finish with a long lingering bitterness ... the dark chocolate and coffee flavors are very solid in this brew ... has a thinner mouthfeel

12oz bottle. Opaque black body. Beige head that thins out after a minute or two. Big coffee aroma. Tyranena owns Imperial Porter. The coffee is quite pronounced, even bigger than the rich bourbon candy touched chocolate malts. Coffee bourbon oatmeal porter, a nice one too.

Pours dark brown with an extremely thin light head. Has a nice coffee aroma with very faint barrel notes. Flavor is also a pleasant coffee with some chocolate. Would like more barrel but its still a solid coffee beer.

Rating #300 for the beer, sweet, 12oz bottle from the 2014 batch, poured into snifter, pours a very dark brown with a red hue in the light, almost black but you can tell its a little lighter, the head is a fast dissipating light brown head, aroma is pretty nice, good amount of chocolate at first with some of the coffee coming through and a kick of bourbon and oak as well, comes together pretty nice, the flavor has a roasty front end with quite a bit of chocolate at first and a hint of vanilla and oak in the finish, the bourbon is there but doesnt go crazy by any means, coffee is there as well, coats the mouth, looking forward to setting a few aside and see what they do.

Bottle. Got to sample this, thanks to my friend Dave, who cellared this for several years. Really delicious beer. I usually dont like coffee stouts/porters because the coffee typically tastes bitter and stale. But this one had the coffee essence without the old coffee nastiness. Nicely balanced with roast malt, a touch of dark fruit, and some wood and bourbon. Everything was quite mellow and integrated -- figure that must be the aging. This was my first Tyranena. Man, I need to plan me some beer road trips to the upper midwest.

12oz bottle, shared by alexsdad06. Bottled on 09 / April / 08. Mostly clear dark brown color. Nice thin light brown head, still, little lace. Very nice bitter roasted turkish coffee in the nose, some chocolate, oats, and light vanilla. Light carbonation, smooth creamy texture, bigger body. Light vanilla, good amount of oat in the flavor, some darker chocolate, great coffee flavor overall that lasts nicely through the aftertaste. Nice bitter taste, some sweet. Tasty imperial porter! Nice big amount of coffee, noticeable but balanced amount of bourbon... Still a decent amount of carbonation, drinking smooth and creamy right now, and flavors are well integrated. Thanks Brad!
Pours black, same rimming as DMMDI, tan head.  Nose of mild coffee and lots of bourbon.  Mild watery coffee and chocolate.  Roast with a bourbon flavor.  meh.

From bottle, courtesy of dpjuart. Nice aroma, vanilla, chocolate, coffee, oak and bourbon. Mellow, sweet, and light vaporous alcohol. A little dusty, papery. Dark black brown clear with thin foamy tan head. Medium-heavy body with light to medium carbonation. Starts sweet and oaky with alcohol, coffee, toffee. Coffee and light smoke and bourbon. Very tasty with light cloying after.

Bottle shared.  Pours a very dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, bourbon and vanilla.  Flavour is medium to heavy sweet and bitter.  Full bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle shared with Plovmand, trade by Bobby91W. Brown body with a small light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, wood, oak, coffee, bourbon. Flavor is coffee, wood, oak, light hops, whisky notes. Well balanced. Fizzy carbonation.

4th October 2010Opaque black - brown beer. Tiny tan head. Lacks the fruity character of the base beer. Replaces it with unsweet wood and very mild bourbon. Mild chocolate in the background. Finishes semi dry. Nice.
Great coffee w/out bitterness, very smooth. Creamy & oily texture. Thin body for an oatmeal stout. Dont really get the bourbon even after warming up completely.

Bottle at home shared and co-traded with Hallinghansen. Thanks Bobby91w. Pours jet black with a medium tan head. The aroma is loads of roasted coffee and malt with notes of oat, oak, light vanilla and cocoa. The flavour is roasted and smooth mellow cocoa and coffee. Some dark fruity notes. Could be from the cellaring. Extremely smooth and quaffable. Very nice!

12oz bottle. Rating #289. Pitch black pour with a thin tan head. Big roasty aroma, smokey with a little ash and some coffee. Light flavor, picking up some vanilla with some mild roast. Tasty stuff. (2091)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text:
35cl bottle.  Aged in my cellar for 3 years and shared with friends.
Decnt off white head.  Deep dark pour.  Lovely beer!  Yummy!

Whole lot going on with this beer, and it all works.  The coffee flavor is immediate, black and strong, yet smooth as the woodsy vanilla of the oak-barrel aging sneaks up.  Chocolate wanders in nonchalantly, then the bourbon sets off a party, until finally the various flavors start going Caligula all over the finish.  Ugly, beheaded and forboding, but ignore these warning signs.  This beer is delicious.  (2008)

12 oz. bottle shared by STLWill- thanks, Will! Pours a deep, dark chocolate brown color with a small tan head. Aroma of peppers, oak, toast, sugar, roasted caramel malts, oats, coffee, and bourbon. Flavor of caramel malts, dry roasted chocolate and coffee, oak, oats, earth, bourbon, vanilla, and peppers. Medium-bodied, with low carbonation a dry, roasty, and spicy mouthfeel. Really interesting beer, and the dry, roasty, coffee notes actually beat out the bourbon barrel notes, which makes for that unusual peppery smell and taste. Enjoyed this one a lot.

12 oz. bottle.  I had this a while back, but cant find the notes so I popped another bottle.  Pours an oily dark brown/black color with a small disappearing tan head.  The aroma has mild barrel notes, black coffee, vanilla, roast and touches of dark chocolate.  It seems to have held up pretty well.  The flavor is similar; coffee is at the forefront, mild smooth bourbon, vanilla, roasted malt, dark chocolate.  There is a slight alcohol burn at the back.  Oxidation is barely noticeable in this bottle.  Pretty smooth, medium plus bodied.  I remember this being hotter fresh and am very impressed with what it has become.

Bottle thanks to Armin who must have aged this properly because its still excellent. Pours black with tan head. Nose of coffee beans, vanilla, oatmeal, rye and chocolate malt. Taste of coffee bean, oatmeal and roast chocolate malt. The coffee beans really dominate the palate. Body could be stronger for an imperial, but overall a very delicious porter. I didnt detect much of the barrel.

Old note, around september 29th 2010. Trade with??? Ok aroma, sweet not a lot of the barrel, oat sweetness brownish black color, no head or lace. Sweet flavor, medium body, smooth mouthfeel, sweet clean finish. Good, flavor still nice. I should of has sooner...
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text:
UPDATED: AUG 20, 2014 Bottle shared by someone at Sea Bass tasting.  

Tragically oxidized, this beer was still fairly tasty but theres a hefty serving of bourbon, slight hints of coffee, and too much cardboard to make me think this beer could be getting any better.  I wish I could have tried it at its peak; there was probably something nice here.  Id advise drinking it now if youve got it.

Rebrewed, rebottled, much improved.  I think I like the regular version more, but this is tasty stuff with nice coffee/cocoa flavors.

Bottle shared by Sean, thanks! Poured a hazy dark brown with a brown head that started and remained at the edges. Aroma had a strong bourbon note as well as a strong coffee note with a bit of dark roasted malts. Flavor was full of dark roasted coffee notes with a bit of bourbon and licorice lying underneath.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 Thanks to Azurelimits for opening this at a recent tasting. Also shared with bmanning, Amyliz4, and hhanson.

A: Pours a nice, deep black. Fairly oily. Nice tan head that thins out but always remains.

S: Loads of coffee (amazing how its kept this for so long!), chocolate, bourbon, molasses, and roasted malt. 

T: A decent amount of sweetness comes in to balance out the crazy combination of coffee, chocolate, and bourbon. Elegant complexity and the perfect balancing act between all the flavors. Nice notes of molasses and brown sugar in the background alongside a bit of roast.

M: Very nice. Medium bodied with lower carbonation leading to a nice smoothness.

D: Pretty intense all around. A great sipper.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-03-2010

Bottled. A deep red beer with a thin brown head. The aroma has notes of malt and over ripe fruits as well as a touch of alcohol. The flavor is sweet with notes of matl, fruit, and tobacco, leading to a dry, bitter, and roasted finish.

(12oz bottle with my likeness on it, Tyranena has not responded to inquires of my likeness being used without permission however, thanks to bu11zeye for this bottle) clearish dark espresso brown. Nose of sweet espresso, fudge, barrel, bourbon, and spicy pepper. Graham cracker and vanilla linger in the nose as well. Smells awesome. Taste of fudge, espresso, caramel, vanilla, bourbon, creamy body and very flavorful. The best Tyranena Ive had!
bottle, thanks to thirdeye11, black brown pour with foam ring, butterscotch and vanilla aroma, flavors of  caramel, chocolate and creamy vanilla finish
Bottle shared with Madvike.  Very smooth, surprised how much coffee was still in there.  No bourbon at all, nose or mouth.  All in all VERY good beer.

Bottle from JCapriotti...thanks Jason! - Pours black with a small foamy tan head. Still a decent amount of coffee...very nice with a bit of bitterness. Aroma has a bit of roast and just a bit of heat. No bourbon, other than a bit of sweetness. Taste smooth vanilla, milky coffee, and sweet chocolate. Finish is abrupt and smooth, with a bit of lingering vanilla sweetness. Still dont taste the bourbon, but its so smooth. Fantastic.

A: snifter. obsidian in color, medium tan head. medium retention rate. mild lacing.

S: huge bourbon aromas, vanilla, coconut, some cherries. big coffee and chocolate notes.

T: major coffee notes, nice balance from the oatmeal. great bourbon flavors, vanilla, coconut and cherries.

M: medium-bodied. mild carbonation level. very smooth and creamy.

D: outstanding. a permanent IV of this would suffice.

Bottle. Pours a black color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty coffee and bourbon aroma with vanilla hints. Has a sweetish smooth roasted malty coffee and bourbon flavor. Sweetish roasted malty bourbon finish with coffee in the aftertaste.

12oz bottle pours a viscous, opaque black with a thin, creamy tan head.  Something very strange and kind of gross floated to the top of my beer.  It was slimy, viscous and had the consistency of snot and caramel.  I fished it out, took some pictures for posterity and moved on.  Nice nose, malty, dark toasted bread, nuts, coffee with cream, brown sugar, a little vanilla, a little toasted oak.  Flavor is malty, sweet, molasses, brown sugar, light smoke, coffee liqueur, whiskey, vanilla, coconut.  Medium bodied and just a little slick.  Good but not great.
Thanks to someone on the RBSG bus! Murky. Tons of coffee. Kinda like my coffee porter from 08. Low carbonation. Something kinda weird, maybe turmeric.

Bottle courtesy of beastiefan2k. Pours a deep brown (almost black) with a small mocha head. The nose is of coffee, chocolate, and a light bourbon barrel alcohol note; a nicely integrated and very pleasant aroma. Medium to full-bodied and slick with a soft carbonation and slightly boozy finish. Mirroring the nose, the flavor is of chocolate, coffee and bourbon barrel (whiskey, oak and vanilla) with an additional mild caramel note thrown into the mix. This is a nice beer. Thanks again for the bottle, Eugene.

This poured basically a black color with a small tan head. Aroma was toasted oats, bourbon, chocolate and more chocolate. Flavor was ridiculously silky smooth, loads of sweet chocolate with a creamy mouth feel, mleded with nice mellow hints of bourbon. Excellent stuff.

Huge thanks to the famous levifunk for this bottle. Aroma of sweet bourbon, milk chocolate, marshmallow and cream. Vanilla beans in the finish with a touch of roasted coffee. Creamy palate gives rise to a beautiful milky, nutty coffee bean infused stout. Bourbon is a great additional flavor, as the aging has taken a backseat to the other elements of the beer. Excellent. One of the best coffee stouts I have had.

Delicious beer, incredible aroma.  I would have loved to try a fresh bottle, but I have no complaints about it aged.  Appearance and feel probably have gone down hill a bit, but the aroma and flavor have the wonderful melded character that comes from age.  The beer pours black, ruby at the edges, with a very small, light brown, dissipating head.  The aroma is chock full of chocolate, coffee, sweet mild bourbon, vanilla beans, oak, wood ash and pleasant alcohol heat.  Its easily the best aroma on a porter Ive encountered and up there even amongst impy stouts.  The flavor is a bit hot but theres also lots of excellent aged malt sweetness, vanilla-y oak and a roasty bitter finish.  The mouthfeel is a tad thin, but it coats the mouth, quite pleasantly.  Wonderful.

A-Body is a completely opaque, dark, deep brown, nearly black color. Beautiful body...but...where is the head? A tiny fizzy <1/2 finger brown head emerges for a few seconds then quickly disappears.

S-Perfect. Exactly what I would want and more in this brew. The nose is on the sweeter side but mixes roasted coffee bitterness, bourbon sweetness, with and added extra hint of vanilla and toffee to top it all off. Smells like a perfectly blended flavored coffee with a shot of bourbon in it?

T-Wonderful. The oak really comes out upfront as well as a big roasted malt background. Its actually much more bitter upfront than at the finish. The bitterness tapers off for the finish where the bourbon and vanilla oak characters really come through. A wonderfully balanced blend of roasted malt, vanilla, toffee, oak, and bourbon flavors linger and a wrapped in a soft warm alcohol blanket.

P-Good, but not as impressive as the taste and smell. Medium to high carbonation and a quite smooth medium weight body. A bit of alcohol comes through in the body.

O-The ABV in this brew is there but pretty well hidden. Overall this is a wonderfully blended beer and probably the best porter that I have ever had. I would trade for it again without hesitation. A really big thanks to EGledhill for this one!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-14-2008 04:23:52

Bottle from a trade with MIBRomeo. Pours black with brown head. Huge coffee aroma. Flavors of coffee, roasted malts, bourbon, vanilla and wood.  Medium to full body with minimal carbonation and a velvety mouthfeel. Excellent brew. Thanks Chuck.

12 ounce bottle given to me several months ago by Joey from South Bay Drugs when I bought a lot of beer there.  Pours mostly black with thin layer of brown foam.  Fantastic aroma of dark roasted coffee along with rich dark chocolate, bourbon, and vanilla.  Taste consists of much of the same as found in the nose with the rich coffee taking center stage as well as other notes of chocolate and bourbon.  A little light in body but creamy and smooth palate.  They really nailed the coffee for this one, and it makes a great dessert beer.  Big thanks to Joey at South Bay Drugs for gifting this excellent (and now retired) beer.  (265, 271)

Bottle from Happy Gnome, awesome! Pours deep black with tan head, aroma is HUGE coffee, like brewed coffee with some bitter coffee beans, working with a slight hint of bourbon, vanilla, and chocolate.  Palate is smooth and creamy from the oatmeal, big complex taste with coffee, chocolate/mocha taste up front leading into some vanilla, bourbon, and caramel sweetness that finishes with a roasted and bitter finish.  Complex, balanced, coffee filled and wonderful.

big thanks to brad for this long time want! nice very dark brown pour with a thick creamy dark brown head and beautiful thick lacing on the glass. aromas meld a good bit of sweet bourbon and bitter coffee to balance it out nicely.  the mouth feel is super creamy, but not super heavy, very, very smooth. the taste is on par with any coffee impy stout i can think of, and the bourbon and coffee are a great combination. the sweet syrupyness of it is cut by the drying bitter roast finish. a great imperial porter with both heavy stout and lighter lager characteristics blended together nicely.

Bottle thanks to ditmier.  Pour is almost black with a small brown head.  Aroma is lots of burnt coffee, roasted malt, light alcohol presence, faint vanilla, and a touch of bourbon.  The burnt coffee is the dominant aroma for sure.  Flavor is  more subtle than aroma.  Still lots of dark roast coffee but with a nice balancing sweetness from the malt.  Bourbon is not an overwhelming force here, more of an afterthought with its presence most noticeable deep into the finish.

Bottled. Blackish coloured. Dense light brown head. Aroma of coffee, sweetness, vanilla, chocolate, wood, ligth roast. Flavour of marzipan, chocolate, sweetness, light roast, light vanilla, light herbs and cocoa. Quite smooth and complex. Medium to full bodied. Has a barreldense, marzipanny and sweet light bitterness in the end. Quite an experience. Huge thx. to Santa Mike for this very nice beer.

Bottle: &nbsp Nearly black, moderate to thin foamy light brown head, a few rings of lacing. &nbsp Strong nose of coffee, soft bourbon. &nbsp Semi-sweet chocolate like roasted malts on the tongue, with a good dose of coffee beans 

and bourbon. &nbsp Certainly comes across as an Oatmeal Porter. &nbsp Amazingly well balanced. &nbsp Finishes with coffee and bourbon notes. &nbsp Sweet lactose lingers. &nbsp This one is amazingly well balanced. &nbsp I wished I had 

more of this. &nbsp Not brash and not over the top, built just right in my opinion. &nbsp Thanks to Skyview for the bottle!

This is the first review Ive decided to do this way, the short way. While I feel that beer reviews are useful...I think that my brief raw feelings toward a beer is more useful.

Brewers Gone Wild Bottle poured into an oversized Duvel glass on 9/8/09

Appearance - black, tan head, 1 finger head, light carbonation

Smell - bitter chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, complex

Taste & Feeling - Smooth sweet chocolate, coffee, sweet roasted malt, medium to heavy mouthfeel, smooth drinker, but still a cokplex sipper

Overall 5 words - delicious, coffee, smooth, drinkable, I wish this wasnt a one time only beer

bottle, pours black with a thin tan head.  Aroma is nice and full of oats and coffee, smells great.  Flavor is wonderful.  Soft bourbon notes with vanilla and a bitter coffee finish with some sweet roasted malt and oat flavors.  Nice porter!

Very lucky to sample this gem at Darkness Day.  Pour is very dark brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is lovely coffee, vanilla, chocolate and a little bourbon.  Flavor is bitter with a little sweet complexity.  Palate is rich, lush, thick, creamy.  Easy to drink and complex.
As you might be able to tell from the beer description, theres a LOT going on here, but it all blends together superbly to make an absolutely delicious sipper of a beer.

Bottle from juiceisloose.  Thanks Justin!  Pours a deep brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, coffee.   Flavor is coffee, bourbon, fruit.  Dry finish.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin.  Good smooth flavorful beer, just didnt pack the same punch of complex or pungent flavors and aromas as other bourbon aged beers.  Enjoyable nonetheless, and Im glad I got to try it!
Nice looking dark brown pour with a tan head, this is a tasty beer. Creamy mouthfeel followed by a nice coffee taste. The vanilla/oak of the bourbon barrels hits you on the finish.

Pours a very dark brown, almost black, small dark tan head, decent lacing.  Aroma obvious of fresh coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate, slight oak, and very very slight bourbon.  Flavor matches well with an additional dried dark fruits, caramel, slight vanilla, and molasses.  Man, this sure seems to have the perfect balance of a lot of flavors and makes for a wonderful drink.  Suprisingly only medium bodied, which likely lended well to it.  Very nice.

Extra from trade with alcstradamus.  Pours dark brown with a small tan head.  Nose is roast, chicory, cocoa, very slight bourbon, earth, and goodness.  Flavor is lots of roast, chicory, sweetness, dark chocolate, and bourbon that hides behind the trees of roast and chocolate.  Bourbon exists here, it is just not the dominant flavor.

Bottle courtesy of markwise. Pours a dark brown to black with thin tan bubbly head. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of chocolate, earth, light bourbon, vanilla, oak, smoke, roast, dark chocolate, brown sugar, hints of cocoa and caramel. Flavor is sweet and smoky with dark bitter chocolate, dark cocoa, roast, coffee, light bourbon, oak, vanilla and hints of light spice. Generally medium body with a malty, lightly smoky and bourbon finish.

Dark brown with red glimts and a medium beige head. Sweet aroma with loads of coffee, dark chocolate, bourbon and hard roasted malt. Sweet flavour with hard roasted malt, dark bitter chocolate, espresso and bourbon. Finished with warming alcohol.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2014 Black pour w/ a thick small bubbled tan head whispy soapy lace.  Big coffee aroma, after that a bi of roasty sweet malts some dry wood notes a hint of vanilla. Palate is a lightly light for the size of it, Id like the oatmeal to add more body.  Flavor is an almost lightly sweet chocolate and vanilla porter w/ an unblended coffee also put in.. and a touch of bourbon in the finish.  now all the flavors are great, but lack balance and blend that would make this an elite beer.

Sampling a bottle from the same 4 pack I originally rated on 8/26/09.
I can say that age REALLY helped this beer, and I think Im going to finish the pack now.  The age mellowed the flavors a bit and gave it a more subtle note as apposed to flavors fighting.  I really enjoyed this tonight.
Rating increased Taste 8->9, Over 16-17.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2013 July 2008:  Tyranena Devil Over A Barrel is dark brown in color with ruby hues.  It has a thin tan-colored head.  The aroma includes a blend of coffee and semi-sweet chocolate as well os kind of a "dirty"/earthy quality.  Flavors include coffee grounds, cherry-vanilla, caramelized malts, and a tinge of alcohol in the nose.  This beer is medium-full in body and smooth is a slight creaminess.  This beer is good and quite enjoyable, but seems too soft.  I was hoping for something a bit more robust.
12 fl. oz. bottle (Bottled on 09 APR 08) from buckybeer via trade.  Thanks Mark!  Rating #250 for this beer.  Score:  7/4/7/4/15 = 3.7
. . . . . . . . . .

12/12/2010:  Tyranena "Devil Over A Barrel" Imperial Oatmeal Porter brewed with Coffee Beans and aged in Bourbon Barrels...  Aroma:  Milky blend of mocha, vanilla, bourbon-soaked barrel char.  Pours out like used motor oil; very little carbonation; dark, murky brown color like sludgy plain coffee; off-white to beige-colored bubbles scattered on the surface.  Appearance:  Flavor:  Coffee with a splash of bourbon and hints of vanilla; soft and smooth chocolate oatmeal in the middle; faint roasty char in the thin, sweet coffee finish; bourbon pops out a bit more clearly as the beer warms; espresso-like bitterness.  Palate:  Medium-full; smooth; maybe a touch thin at times.  Overall:  Interesting flavor combination of coffee, oatmeal, and bourbon; the regular, non barrel-aged quivalent (Tyranena The Devil Made Me Do It) is better in just about every way.
12 fluid ounce bottle.  Score:  7/3/7/4/14 = 3.5

aroma is of vanilla and coffee without any acidic tones. appearance is 10W-30 with zero carb. flavor is of vanilla, acidic french pressed coffee, general booze, soft bourban and general whiskey notes, clean belgian chocolate, chocolate covered espresso beans.  this is the only beer ive had of the style that gives breakfast stout a run for its money, this is phenominal.  bourban hardly interferes with the already strong imperial porter elements, it coincides and assists where in other beers it shatters the formers success. big thanks to pat from RG binnys for the bottle! (my neck label actually says the devil made me do it, and the main label claims this is devil over a barrel....the proof is in the taste, and this is clearly bourboned).
Aroma is of strong coffee, really brilliant smelling.  Flavor very similar to aroma.  Very interesting brew.

Bottle, thanks to tytoanderso. Aroma of huge coffee beans with a touch of vanilla floating around. Flavor continues to be huge on the coffee bean front with more of an influence from the bourbon creating a sweet feeling around the edges, and really melding with the coffee beans, delicately dousing them with the bourbon. Great stuff.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2009 Bottle.  Pours brown with a small ring of head.  Aroma of coffee beans, roasted malt, and roasted nuts.  Wow, awesome coffee aroma!!  Flavor is not quite as powerful--more coffee, bourbon, roasted nuts, iced tea, and sweet malt.  A touch sweet.  A nice example of a bourbon-aged beer that is NOT dominated by the bourbon.  Great coffee beer (although the aroma is better than the flavor).
9/4/8/4/15 (4.0/5)
Update 7/25/09: This bottle wasnt as sweet as I remembered from my previous tasting.  More chocolate cake-like notes.  Very delicious so Im bumping it up a poiny.  Clearly superior to Devil Made Me Do It.
9/4/8/4/16 (4.1/5)

12oz bottle via trade with FlandersNed. pours a beautiful, slightly oily black with a thin, mocha head a light lacing. aroma is wonderful and hugely complex with big notes of roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and bourbon with lighter elements of vanilla and smoke, and a touch nuts and of dark fruits. flavor is fantastic with massive roast coffee and cream up front with notes of chocolate and vanilla extract backed by dark, roasted malts, a light sweetness, and lovely subtle, oaked bourbon flavors throughout. palate is smooth as silk owing to the oatmeal elements with low carbonation and a lingering coffee finish with a slight touch of bourbon. overall, this is expertly crafted barrel aged brew that truly improves the already excellent Devil Made Me Do It.

12oz pours dark brown though not black with a very small tan head.  Aroma is intense coffee beans and chocolate.  Coffee is a real standout here.  I dont know when this was brewed but I know its not fresh, but this coffee aroma is one of the most intense Ive ever experienced.  Stronger than Founders Breakfast.  Its a good coffee smell too, fortunately.  Chocolate and vanilla notes also prominent, slight bourbon and oak quality but you gotta look.  Flavor is bourbon and chocolate, nice taste though the body is a bit thin for my tastes.  Really nice coffee aroma, good subtle bourbon throughout with a nice flavor.  If this were a bit heftier in the mouthfeel department it would be significantly better.  This is still solid though.

Courtesy Ughsmash. A coffee-forward BA impy porter. I like the fact that the bourbon and barrel elements arent the stars of this brew. Plenty of roast, chocolate, and bittersweetness. Full body, moderate/light carbonation. Great brew.

Thanks to Sneagrams03 (Andy)!

Aroma is bourbon, chocolate, some char, roast, and traces of sourness.  Yum!
Initially pours with no head, but some light brown lacing is apparent afterwards. Color is rich, dark brown- no light penetrates.

Taste is big, brash, well-carbonated:
Alcohol is the first thing to hit me, then a chalky chocolate, roast, and some bourbon and char and sourness on the back end. Smoke, char, bourbon, chocolate.
How could I not like this?
Well integrated.
Very good.


More of a coffee-bitte rbackbone is starting to come out of this bad boy as it warms. Makes a full, rich, malty appearance that accents the chocolate, char, and bourbon well.
More vanilla coming out, too.

12oz Bottle  Trade - JJClark
Aroma: Huge bourbon aroma and dark malt aroma.  
Appearance: Dark Brown in color, clear with a thin head.  
Flavor: Big flavors of oak, bourbon dark malts.  This was full of flavor.   
Palate: Dry finish, with a Good Barrel Mouthfeel.

Pours an extremely dark brown body almost black in color topped by a foamy, tan colored head that leaves minimal lacing behind. The aroma is very nice showing roasted espresso, dark cocoa, cream, and a hint of bourbon. The flavor is just as nice showing more of the roasted espresso, dark chocolate, and some earthy bitter hops. The bourbon is well integrated and shows itself on the finish adding some nice depth. Medium bodied mouthfeel that is very smooth and creamy with some moderate carbonation leading to bourbon espresso finish. This is a really well done porter and a nice subtle use of the bourbon barrels.

Pours translucent very dark brown with a  tan ring of foam.  Peppery aroma with a bit of chocolate behind it. Light body and carbonation. The taste is also peppery at first, then opens up woody vanilla and chocolate. Lots of wood and some ash and chocolate on the finish.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of pepsican/iowaherkey. Pours a dark brown - almost black - with a warm reddish hue and a light brown head. Very burned coffee aroma. Medium body, hard roasted malt, coffee, ashes, sweet vanilla and bourbon. Some malt bitterness in the finish. 290509

Bottle acquired via trade.  Wow.  This is the first Tyranena Ive had and its really impressive.  Black in color with a beige head.  Lots of coffee on the aroma, along with roast, chocolate, and barrel notes.  Flavor is fresh coffee city with chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla, oak, bourbon, and spice.  Well-balanced with a medium-full body.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2009 #32 - Amerikaner Blind-Smagning 29-Maj-2009 hos Papsoe. Bottle. Black - offwhite head. High coffee, burned, vineous, wood, oakey, vanilla, bourbon, chocolate, roasted, grinded coffee. Lovely balanced. - Again: Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks to CaptainCougar. Ƙ/4/8/4/17)

12oz bottle shared by ogglethorp.  Darkest brown pour with a thin beige head.  Malty aroma with coffee, vanilla and a bit of metal.  Vanilla and oak flavors up front followed by bourbon and finishing with chocolate and coffee.  Very good, but I think I like it better before the bourbon aging.

Dark brown coloured with a medium sized beige head.

From bottle, blind #32. Poursdark brown to black with a small tan head. Dense coffee and roasted malt aroma. Slight herbal. Dry and sweet crisp flavoured with a distinct coffee flavour. Light herbal to spiced note aswell. Bitter and roasted coffee finish.

Bottle from Monger - thanks so much, James; still whittling down that massive shipment you sent me.  I fear I may have let this one sit too long.  Aroma is defined - ashy chocolate, coffee beans and roast - but not very big or full. Aroma of wood, pecans, hazelnut and very mellow and "beany" coffee beans, light bourbon, and unsweet dark chocolate.  Tastes wonderful really, better than I imagined a coffee porter tasting!  Sweet wood and caramel, bourbon, followed by dark chocolate, vanilla and pecans.  Finishes like toasted pecans dipped in like 80% cocoa, and a very pleasant lingering wood aftertaste. so so awesome! .. thanks john .. . smmoth as silk .. . no abv even close to being there .. . "football or beer" .. . beutiful stuff .. . to much fun to drink.. . i am honored to have drunk this .. .
Nice and heavy onthe bourbon. Smooth, vanilla and cremy coffee notes. Sweet molasses round it out. Nice.

i absolutely love davil made me do it, however sadly, this comes in second.  pours black with very little head.  heavy coffee nose with some roast.  mouthfeel is thick and oily.  taste is very compareable to made me do it, but theres a sweetness left by the bourbon barrel aging.  great beer, although i got a slimey loogy-like surprise in one of my sips.  i told myself it was related to the beer and not some disgruntled employee spitting in the vat.  love tyranena, hate loogies.

Dark brown with ruby highlights topped off by a tan crown that slowly recedes.  The aroma is dominated by strong coffee with a backbone of bourbon, oatmeal and roasted malt.  Taste of coffee, roasted malt, bourbon, alcohol, oatmeal and something sweet, perhaps milk sugar.  Super smooth body is a touch sticky and finishes up dry and roasty, warm and toasty.  Pretty solid offering  Im starting to come around on these bourbon aged beers when bourbon is the accentor and not the dominator.

Bottle, shared by sauceyhops at Pats 24th birthday party in Carlsbad. Thanks Gabe! Soft carbonation. Aroma is medium strength coffee bean, with a light hint of bourbon sticking out. Oak and whiskey are a bit restrained in the flavor, but noticeable. The dominant character is still held by creamy coffee and roasted malt. A light sweetness prolongs the flavor. Dry, thin finish. Very easy to drink. Yum!

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2009 Courtesy of northernbrews
Bottle : Strong roasted coffee aroma along with caramel, bourbon, and fruit.  The aromas seem to clash rather than blend together very well.  It pours a dark brown with no transparency and a small beige head.  The flavor starts with chocolate and a fruity backbone.  The finish has some watery bourbon flavors and mild roasted coffee.  Medium bodied that comes across slightly thin due to minimal carbonation.

12 oz bottle graciously given to me by beastiefan2k.  Pour is mostly clear black, brown with some ruby notes.  Nice one inch tan head.  Nice looking beer.  Aroma of roasted coffee maltiness, Bourbon, wood and some pine hoppiness, though that is very slight and in the background.  The nose is mostly about the coffee and Bourbon.  Taste is sharp Bourbon and wood initially, then a blast of fairly flat coffee.  Behind that is a nice roasty maltiness, some silky oatmeal, finishing with the pine bitter hops.  There is a lot of flavor in this beer, and it makes transitions between flavors well enough.  However, the coffee flavor was just a little too stale for me to love it and the Bourbon was a bit to upfront for me.  Palate is medium, slick and does not entirely cover the perceived alcohol burn from the Bourbon.  This was a well made beer, just not entirely my thing.  Thanks for giving me this one Eugene.
awesome blend of coffee,oatmeal,and just a hint of barrel aging.i have enjoyed every tyranena i have ever had.

Aroma of coffee with underlying bourbon barrel notes of vanilla, and light sweet booze. Smells very nice. Pours dark brown with a nice mousy brown head that settles into some islands. Flavors of roast, coffee, dark malts, light bourbon, vanilla, earthy notes. Dry coffee/oak/earthy finish. Lots of lingering roasted coffee beans. Very dry mouth feel. Really freaking good.

bottle thanks to mar, i have been waiting for this one.  pour was black with a tan head that fades.  aroma of dark roasts.  flavor was the same with the addition of alcohol.  medium body with no carb.  this was pretty good stuff, not bad at all.

12 oz. bottle, courtesy of Skyview.  Dark black pour with a thin, tan head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate, and vanilla.  Mouthfeel is smooth and velvety.  Flavor really takes the cake.  Tons of coffee, chocolate, and bourbon notes.  Finish is slightly bitter and smoky.  Definitely a knock out.
Bottle thanks to Mar. Black brown pour with no head. Nose is wood, chocolate, and java, and vanilla. Taste is about the same. Good mouthfeel and very mild to drink. Lingering finish.

Bottle thanks to mar. Pours a deep, dark brown with tan head. Aroma of dark roast and chocolate. Flavor of dark roast, baking chocolate, espresso. Mouthfeel is very nice, silky with a heavy body. Overall, good stuff!

12 oz bottle from Walt!!! Thanks a bunch! Nose of coffee, caramel, chocolate, and light vanilla. Opaque black, brown edges, with a small tan head. Flavor of coffee, coffee, and more coffee with some chocolate, and some very light bitterness. Excellent!

12 oz bottle - Poured coffee black with hint of ruby on edges. Small tan head that faded quickly. Nice lacing on glass!
Aroma - Rich black COFFEE beans and vanilla.
Flavor - Awesome coffee and some coconut taste. Like eating a mounds bar with a cup of joe.

Overall - I am impressed!!! The aroma is amazing and taste is better. I am not a huge coffee drinker but this is a better alternative!! This beer is so good its scary!!?? GO AND TRY THIS BEER!!!

Bottle courtesy of hellbilly.  Pours a rich coffee color with a faint tan head.  Smells incredible.  Brimming with smoke and bourbon that carry into the flavor along with notes of vanilla, brown sugar, and coffee.  The oatmeal seems to bind everything together.   Cant wait to have this again just so I can reaffirm how amazing this beer is.

Bottle from Discount Liquors.  I think the original Devil made me do it was amazing, and was anxious to try the barrel-aged version.  Pours dark-brown, nearly black with quickly fading tan head.  Aroma is loaded with oak, coffee, and molasses.  Flavor is much the same with bourbon being the dominant force.  Theres also oak, dark fruit, vanilla, and it finishes with moderate astringency.  Medium-body.  This is an awesome beer.  If I had to choose, I still think I would stick with the regular Devil, even though I like this quite a bit.

Bottle thanks to mar. Pours with a brown head that leaves early and a very dark brown body underneath. Aroma has tons of bitter, fresh roast, vanilla, bourbon, French vanilla, lactose and chocolate. Taste is light bourbon, chocolate, roast, chocolate milk, and lactose. Syrupy mouthfeel and light carbonation.
pitch black pour with no head.   nose of coffee, roasted malts and some bourbon.  great on the palate with  a heavy fresh coffee flavor and a bourbon finish.

Dont get me wrong, this is a good brew.  The line between porter and stout is further brewed, but I guess it really comes across in the mouth as this is thinner than I had hoped.  The bourbon is not very prominent, but does make an appearance.  If you like Peche Mortel, youll like this one.  Its basically a more coffee forward version of that.

My Bottom Line:
Bounteous coffee surrounds the caramel malts and vanilla-like bourbon notes in this lascivious and silky strong ale creation for sweet teeth.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A ring of foam circles the blackness.
-The aroma is pretty much as enticing as Péché Mortels own coffee-laden nose.
-Carbonation is relatively smooth, letting all the malts express themselves thoroughly.
-Roasted malts diversify the sweet malt profile.
-Is it me or are oatmeal and coffee often a match made in heaven in these strong dark ales?

Bottle; merci beaucoup Dany!!!

Dark brown color, with a very light tan head. Espresso nose, lacking depth. Dark roast coffee up front, with a light note of caramel as well. No barrel character. Not much in terms of malt depth. My main complaint though, its not bottle conditioned....just tastes dead, which leads to a poor mouth feel as well.

Dark chestnut body is opaque in the glass but pours dark and clear. Cocoa head retains well and leaves lots of sticky lace. Bold aroma of fresh roasted coffee beans, vanilla, and malted milk chocolate. Silky medium full body has moderate carbonation. Taste opens with malted milk chocolate balls, quickly overrun by the assertive coffee character. Roasted almonds and vanilla notes add complexity. Really well done but the assertive coffee character becomes a bit too much in the end.

Poured a dark mahogany color with a small, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, smoke, coffee, vanilla, chocolate, and bourbon.  Taste of roast, vanilla, some smoke, chocolate, wood, and bourbon / alcohol in the finish. Thanks to Walt for sharing!

Pours a deep black with a small light brown head. Aroma is huge roasted espresso, roasted malts, wood, vanilla and bourbon. Flavor is good coffee, malt, wood, touch of bourbon. courtesy of retorp.
Pours deep black with beige head.

Pours dark brown with a nice brown head.  Really a pretty wonderful aroma of chocolaty malts, oaky bourbon, and black coffee.  Same with the flavors, and all are perfectly blended.  Fluffy marshmallow mouthfeel and a dry finish.  Damn fine beer.

Pours dark black with thin tan head.  Aroma of bourbon, coffee, and a little chocolate.  A well done porter, I wish I had more than just one bottle.  Good bourbon flavor and a lot of coffee.  Quality brew.
This is a really, really good beer.  Lots of coffee in the nose and across the palate.  Pretty thin over the tongue, but to be expected from a porter style.  Finishes clean.  Nice beer.

Pours a dark black like coffee.  The Nose of vanilla, oak, molasses, and bourbon. Flavor definitely exhibits the barrel aging, accentuating the chocolate and roasted coffee rather than overpowering them. Medium mouthfeel. Still overall a well done porter.

Aroma of vanilla, oak, molasses, and bourbon.  Flavor definitely exhibits the barrel aging, accentuating the chocolate and roasted coffee rather than overpowering them.  Didnt get as much oatmeal in this as the description would lead you to believe.  Medium mouthfeel.  Really enjoyed this beer...extremely flavorful
Bottle. Chocolate, vanilla, oak, coffee and bourbon. Some roasted ash in the finish. Would get again.

Tyranena Brewer Gone Wild! releases have always been top notch.  This is close to the top of a competitive selection of releases.  I wish there were more people making imperial porters as I could drink them every day of the week.
