text: (Thanks for sharing, kmweaver).  You de man, Ken!  Dark brownish black, tan creamy head.  Deep roasted coffee and cream aromas warm to notes of oaken vanilla and coconut bourbon.   Smooth intense sugared coffee and chocolate oatmeal flavors balance extremely well on soft vanilla and bourbon wood tones.   Medium bodied, soft carbonation, bittersweet finish.  A great example of how to utilize the barrel.  Awesome...

Pours black with a nice tan head.  Aroma is huge coffee.  Taste is similar to the regular devil, lots of coffee, with some sweeter notes rounding it out a bit more.  Vanilla and some cream.  Very nice, thanks Pepsican.

So good Im glad I bought 2 cases of this.  The beer pours to a pitch black body with a thin creamy medium light brown head.  The aroma is insanely coffee laden.  Aromatic chocolate, sweet barley, rye malt, chocolate revel bars like Mom makes, oatmeal, and subtle vanilla barrel.  The flavor is coffee, sweet barley, oatmeal, vanilla, crystalline chocolate sauce, milky sweet sugars.  Superbly balanced.  The palate is sweet, sugary, intensely malty but clean.  Medium bodied with a super long finish.

Translucent and licorice black in color with a tan foam cap riding on top. Prevalent, stale coffee beans take the nose with touches of black earth, unsweetened cocoa and burnt graham crackers. Alluring, but not captivating until first sip. Flavor amplifies the nose and draws out an eloquent Godiva milk chocolate liquor truffle. Sweet caramel ribbons course through toasted honey graham cracker crumbs with cocoa nibs, hazelnut coffee grinds and a dash of sweet bourbon to seal the deal. Unassuming body rest confidently on its complimentary carbonation, as the bourbony chocolate malt sweetly sings with whiskey cocoa toffee, pressed onto the tongue and holding long unto the night. Best thing this brewery has done in two years.

Thanks pantanap for sharing this one.  One for the train ride.  Pitch black with a medium fluffy tan head.  Aroma is very big coffee, dry and roasted malt.  Dry coffee flavor with medium sweetness, roasted malt, a little pine. Medium body with a little creaminess.  Overall a very nice coffee forward stout and well balanced.  Thanks again Kan.

bottle. pours rich dark brown, almost black. dark tan head and nice lacing. Aroma of dark roast coffee and  chocolate. Starts with a roasted malt, chocolate, and smokiness. Turns semi sweet some vanilla, licorice, and rye. Very subtle bourbon and is balanced well.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2008 On tap at Buster’s.  Pours an opaque, dark brown, almost black body with rich dark brown head.  Aroma of coffee and roasted malts with a touch of smoke and bourbon.  Thick, smooth mouthfeel with a medium to heavy body.  The taste is dominated by a dark roasted coffee/espresso flavor with vanilla, oak, oatmeal, smoke, and caramel flavors also present.  The taste of bourbon comes out as the beer warms, but still complements the coffee and other flavors without becoming too dominant.  Coffee and smoky finish.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Bottle, courtesy Guerde. Pours a dark black, with caramel-colored highlights, and a decent head and lacing. Giant roasted coffee in the nose, some oats, and a chalky chocolate factor. Chocolate flavors, roasted malts, coffee, and caramel in the finish. Decent hoppiness lingers in the mouth. Smooth, medium-bodied, very drinkable and feels like velvet, very balanced.

Courtesy hopscotch.  Pours black with a small off white head.  Smells of big fresh coffee grounds, dark toasty malts, and vanilla beans and chocolate.  The taste wasmostly of the coffee and chocolate with just mild touches of the bourbon coming through.  Seems like the coffee outweighed it.  Got touches of smoke and vanilla in the aftertaste, but the coffee was easily the most dominant flavor.  I really dug this, I thought it was going to be a bigbourbon bomb, but it was nicely balanced for a bourbon barrel beer.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2008 6/15/08 re-rate. The first time I had this beer I had multiple Imperial Stouts before I got around to this one and wanted to give it a fresh rating. Original score was 3.5.
Bottle courtesy Degarth. Pours almost black with a small tan head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, oats and just a hint of bourbon. Taste is the same as aroma with a touch of sweet caramel. Medium thin mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness and smooth alcohol. Very good.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2008 Courtesy of Pepsican.  Bottle pours a pitch black.  Smells like a starbucks coffee with some beer on the side.  Tastes like a dark coffee and has a wonderful taste.  Coffee, chocolate, coffee, vanilla, coffee, syrup, coffee, oak, and coffee.  Has a silky medium mouthfeel.  Overall, this is one of the best brews I have ever had.

(12oz bottle, thanks kmweaver) Murky dark brown body with medium tan head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, coffee, chocolate, some cream, light vanilla.  Taste is moderately sweet, coffee, chocolate, some vanilla.  Chococoffee finish.  Creamy medium body, some syrup, low carbonation.  Great to discover that Tyranena has a barrel-aged beer worthy of the hype (ok, I liked Whos Your Daddy too (but this one more)).

Dark brown pour.  Thin tan head with an attractive lacing.  Coffee is the primary aroma, with the bourbon playing in the background.  The flavor complexity is very nice.  Lighter bourbon, which instead of overwhelming the senses, just is an additive which adds to the aura of this beer.  The oatmeal flavor is a nice touch which adds to the smoothness for this.  IMO an improvement over the original Devil Made me Do it.  Very well done and a favorite from Tyanena.  The bourbon aspect here is perfect.

12oz bottle, thanks, pepsican. Pours dark brown, with a quickly fading tan head. Aroma is strong coffee, chocolate, malt, and very slight touches of bourbon. Flavor is coffee, chocolate, vanilla, and only a slight bit of bourbon. One of the few bourbon barrel brews that could use more of a bourbon flavor.  Still, highly enjoyable.

12oz bottle, courtesy of pepsican.  Thanks, Andy!  Pours a murky, dark chocolate color; medium tan head with patchy lacing.  Loads of well-roasted coffee, toasty vanilla, oak and just a light touch of bourbon; gorgeous, dense aroma with a nice milky coffee character.  Relaxed carbonation.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: lots of chocolate, well-roasted coffee and cream, roasted malts; great coffee character, and a touch of molasses; excellent stuff.  Lengthy finish: breadiness, toasted and roasted grains, chocolate and coffee.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2015 Bottle shared by kmweaver.  Pours a viscous dark brown, clinging to the glass with considerably strong legs for the ABV thats known.  First whiff is an impressively bright and green coffee aroma, along with some peppery chocolate malt, some peaty compost and gritty earthiness.  Flavor is another chapter in this story: significantly more of a chocolate syrup note, along with bourbon and some dried, charred wood.  Overall very decadent and delicious, the coffee is bright and green, which sometimes I dont like so much but I can dig it in this beer.  I dont get any oatmeal, but what I do get  coffee, wood, bourbon, chocolate  its put together quite well.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2008 Bottle, courtesy of Tim in line at DLD and then again at the brewery on draft, then courtesy of Vferg.  This is my kind of a beer.  Coffee beans with a quiet expression of bourbon, vanilla with a creamy finish, a dangerously awesome treat. Great!  4.3
ReRate: 7/4/08 this is liquid java i cant get enough of it, im trading for more. 4.5

Bottle, with another big THANK YOU to Tyler (tytoanderso) for this treat!  Pours a dark brown with a towering creamy light brown head that lingers forever, covering the entire glass in thick, sticky lace.  Aroma is freshly ground coffee, brown sugar, vanilla and chocolate, all nicely blended together.  Flavor continues on a similar vein, with only a slight bit of bourbon that comes out as well and compliments nicely.  The palate is silky, creamy and full.  Every bit as enjoyable and a slight notch better than the Devil Made Me Do It; quite good.

Pours black with a creamy, medium light brown head.  Aroma heavy on coffee and sugar, some chocolate and a hint of bourbon.  Taste is coffee up front, chocolate in the middle with a light bourbon chaser, the bourbon is very light and not overpowering at all.  Mouthfeel is silky smooth and this is very easy drinking.  I thought I might be disappointed with this for some odd reason, maybe because this series of beers seems to be very similar lately, but I am really enjoying this one.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2008 Pours black with a thin dark tan head. Strong coffee aroma, a touch of chocolate and bourbon. Decent flavor, nice mouthfeel. Rerate - Aroma is less coffee, more bourbon and chocolate. Flavor is more mellow.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2009 Coffee flavor is impressive.  Bourbon is hardly tasted but that was not a bad thing.  Loved everything about this beer.

*Edit* after trying this again after almost a year of it sitting all that comes through is the bourbon.  Very mellow and pretty thick.  It was like having a completely different beer since the first time I tried it.  Both equally as good in their own ways.

12 oz bottle thanks to pantanap for sharing this one on the metra ride home.  Coffee and chocolate are strong in the nose.  Lots of coffee beans with burnt malts.  Coffee and chocolate malt flavors.  The coffee tastes old, possibly on account of the barrel.  The more I drink it the more the coffee becomes unenjoyable.  A touch of bourbon rounds out the flavor.  Decent.
Flossmoor tasting. Pours black. Strong smells of coffee. This is like coffe in a bottle with sugar and a bit of carbonation. Hint of breadiness. Medium bodied. low carbonation. Mild sourish finish.
Nice dark in color good lasting head. Rich full taste of the  coffee and chocolate and hint of bourbon

12oz bottle.  thanks to ughs for hooking me up with a bottle of this pre-dld..... pours dark brown with a very thin film of light brown head..... aroma dominated by rich coffee grounds and backed up by chocolate.  very little bourbon... flavors of fresh coffee beans, chocolate malt with just a smidge of barrel presence....i liked this just a little bit better than the non-barrel version.

Pours a rich black with thin light brown head that fades quickly.  Aroma is intense rich coffee aroma, chocolate. light vanilla and bourbon.  However, the coffee dominates in the nose.  Taste is coffee upfront, light chocolate, vanilla and bourbon shows up in the finish.  Moderate carbonation and alcohol is well hidden.  This is damn good, however, Tyranena needs to change up the BGW series with something different then extreme porters.  With that said, Rob, you did a great job with this one.

12oz bottle acquired in trade with ughsmash (thanks!). Poured a dark black color with an averaged sized tan head. Aromas of coffee grounds, roast, bourbon, some wood, smoke, oats, and vanilla. Tastes of coffee, vanilla, bourbon, chocolate, some wood, and roast.  Alcohol well hidden. This one has some of my favorite things in a beer (coffee and bourbon) and it didnt dissapoint me. The bourbon wasnt overpowering  and worked well (must be 60/40 blend).

Black color with a very quickly vanishing head.  Strong aroma of coffee, vanilla, a little oak and very faint oatmeal.  Tons of oats and smooth coffee flavor.  A bit of lactose sweetness.  The oak and vanilla fade a bit.  The bourbon is barely noticeable.  Delicious.

12oz bottle. thanks to pantanap for sharing. pours black with thin off white head. a huge coffee aroma, hazelnuts. flavors are chocolate, coffee, caramel, held together nicely by subtle hints of bourbon. the barrel has really improved devil made me do it. a sweet coffee finish. fizzy mouth feel. really tasty beer.

(bottle) This "edgy" beer pours out black with a tan head that leaves nice lacing, but doesnt really linger.  Aroma was initially dominated by bourbon, but then quickly shifted to dark roasted coffee, which then changed to a salty almost peanut-butter like scent with some wood too. Theres also some chocolate that makes a presence, but the nice bourbon scent that was there in the beginning has not really come back. Taste has a tartness up front, but then flavors of chocolate, bourbon, roasted malt, and coffee are present as well.  The finish is full of roastiness, with just a light hint of alcohol. Mouthfeel is rather full.  This isnt too bad.

[Bottle, thanks Guerde!] Pours dark brown with an almost non-existent dark tan head. Aroma is bourbon, a blast of deeply roasted coffee, a hint of alcohol and just a little chocolate. Taste is also overpowered with coffee, but after the initial wave it subsides into chocolate and bourbon with some alcohol and roasted malt present. Medium mouthfeel and smooth with a long finish. The domination of the aroma by the harsh coffee detracted from it, but it was overall still a fairly solid beer.

[bottle] Poured a very dark brown, almost black, with a tan head that took a little coaxing to form. Aroma is fairly one sided, but not in a bad way, of freshly ground coffee beans. Also in the aroma is some vanilla/oak, bourbon, and roasted barley. Flavor is very nice, with coffee being the most prominent intially which fades in favor of well balanced bourbon. I have to agree with Stine that a little less carbonation would have made this much better. Not terribly bitter on the finish. Overall a very good beer.

Leaving work.  About to seek out a beer Im likely to hate.  My preconceived dismissal of anything rashly attempting to harness the subtleties of coffee through a hopeless medium or to siphon away unpleasantries through bourbon aging just seems envisioned for this one alone.  Stop myself, thinking why after all; I dont care about rocking the boat or going against the grain.  For the experience, possibly.  For the reassurance that my personal biases are in fact those that I imagine to be most correct.  For a new experience with malt, hops and yeast, and affectations.  Most of all, for the intriguing opportunuity to have those biases proven too limited and too uninformed; to have my haughtiness undercut by something that seems so much a caricature of itself and of brewing in general and to have my vision broadened.  The discovery begins with a tap pour at the Happy Gnome. 

Pours dark brown with ruby highlights and a brimming ring of tanned cream.  Aroma first brings coffee ice cream and espresso machines being cleaned.  Tart presence of dark chocolate with berry leanings and some cinnamon and vanilla impartation.  Burst of german chocolate cake warming through the closing half.  Acrid, certainly; coffee of an oxidized stripe, while bourbon settles it a bit, and plays no unfavorable part of its own.  Flavor is impish and inexpressively sweet; lots of toasted coconut and vanilla, bakers chocolate, old coffee thats taken on the character of a wet brown bag, and some healthy, juicy roastiness.  Mid palate is mostly vegetal tartness and cloying hints of burnt milk and oversugared coffee.  Texture is frothy and of a medium body, with an obnoxiously jagged base beneath a silky surface.  Throughout, the immediate tones of aroma and flavor are quite pleasant, but as the beer breathes these retreat and wither; the acridity and ugly buttery sweetness enfolding with a suffocating, grotesque force.  Altogether, the bourbon aging seems more to soften things a bit than to provide any kind of dominant flavors, which is salutary for the overall impression.  Finishes with lots of sweetened coffee, burnt caramel, and a warming, rich hint of seared rare steak that lingers quite beautifully, providing a bit of restitution there.  


Unfulfilled curiousity settles in.  An odd challenge approached with an open mind, while not fully predictable in its outcome, produced in the end a very ordinary result; this does nothing to push the boundaries or to show what possibilties there are for brewing with coffee for uniqueness or stashing in a barrel for slow sophistication or for temperance.  Admittedly, theres no reason why that should have been the point, but its certainly the reason why for me, my biases are proven justified in this case.

12oz bottle. Aroma of under roasted cold press, green pepper, chocolate and a fairly heavy charred wood presence. Pours a dark, near opaque brown with a dense mocha head. Charred wood, bakers chocolate, cold press on the tongue. Theres a touch of steel and toasted vanilla bean. Fairly silky on the tongue. Good carbonation. The finish is a tad weak. Some bitter chocolate and coffee notes fade quickly. Yet another slightly better than average coffee porter. As expected.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2008 Bottle pours black and rich with a large tan head and interesting lace.  The aroma is coffee, molasses, light peat, vanilla, and dark chocolate.  The flavor has one of those taste one thing first, then another, then another things going on.  It starts out mild and chocolaty, morphs into a more roasted coffee, changing into dark fruits, with a lingering vanilla sweetness.  The palate is creamy, but not sticky, and lively.  Overall, this is a good beer.  Im glad I got two of the four packs.  Thanks Tyler at Zipps!  Update next day:  this is one of the rare times I would say that I liked it better cold.

I loved this beer it had all the flavors and aspects of a good porter with alot of coffee and bourbon flavors,it poured a pitched black and had a creamy finish which was a great blend,overall a awesome porter.CHEERS!

Pitch black pour with a medium sized espresso head.  Aroma was strong oat and coffee.  Flavor had plenty of coffee up front and a bit of breakfast in the middle.  That faded into a nice bourbon finish with oak and vanilla.  Very interesting here.  None of the flavors seem overly strong,  but they blend together nicely to create a pretty intense beer.  Finished creamy,  very nice.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2008 Pours a pitch black with a thin mocha head, only if you do an aggressive pour - the head fades very quickly.  Aroma is heavily dry coffee grounds with some vanilla, almost reminds me of the Meantime Coffee Porter, but with more of an organic coffee aroma.  The taste is very smooth, strong coffee here with hints of vanilla, oak, and bourbon, but finishes a bit dry for me.

Im going to agree with ol ThirstyNeck. The coffee aspect of this brew is amazing, as it has more coffee then any brew I have had, but what seperates it is the smoothness and balance of the coffee and the bourbon. The bourbon aspect is pretty subdued, but its there, with a little sweetness at the end. The coffee is so smooth, creamy, roasty, good.  I didnt think they could top the regular Devil from last year, but this has just that little extra that makes it the perfect brew for me.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2008 Incredible. I love coffee beers, and the original devil was something to write home about. However, this one is insane.  Everything about it is just perfect. The bourbon is not overpowering at all, there is just enough hints of chocolate,  sweet vanilla, and oaky toastiness in this one.
Amazingly smooth and creamy on the tongue, and a real treat as it parties on the palate for quite some time. The aroma is of dark heavily roasted coffee with a touch of vanilla and sweet bourbon, but just a touch.

Cant say much else besides wow........yep best coffee brew ive had yet. Though there are many great ones!

I must add to this AGAIN!  The more i drink the more incredible it is. I have 30 bottles but cannot bring myself to drink them out of fear of what ill do when its gone!  Swish it in your mouth a bit and swallow it... wait a few seconds and lick between teeth and gums.....OH MY OH MY.! Woooooo

On draught at the brewerys taproom in Lake Mills, Wisconsin. Pours an opaque dark brown brew with a thick and creamy tan head that slowly dissolves and leaves behind a retaining head and some spotty lacing. Aroma of mostly coffee, espresso, and more coffee. I could pick up just a hint of roasted dark malt and a touch of vanilla and amarillo. Taste is full bodied, thick and chewy with flavors of deep roasted coffee, dark chocolate, some vanilla and roasted dark malt. Finish is when the bourbon flavors come out with a decent aftertaste of dark chocolate, bourbon and some coffee character. Another excellent beer in the Brewers Gone Wild series.

Dark brown color with a seafoam tan head. Heavy coffee aromas. Actually only coffee aromas, some espresso and latte mixes, but certainly coffee. I am now catching some dark chocolate after a minute or so of sniffing, but still coffee. If you like coffee and dont like the scent of this one... well what do I know. Smooth and lightly oily on the palate. This one glides very gently across the tongue. Quite sweet with sugared coffee, light caramel, toasted malt and hint of vanilla. Bourbon takes its time coming out in this one and only really sticks out in the vanilla and when held on the tongue for a significant period of time. Nice blend. Im not sure how the bottles will hold up, but I would wager a keg of this in a few year will be a smooth, decedent elixir.

Bottled on April 9.  Poured a lovely deep brown with a creamy, well-formed cap of dark tan head.  My first impression from the aroma was of heavy, freshly-ground darker-roasted coffee.. vanilla and oak waft through, but not a lot of bourbon in the nose..  rich and inviting, as I loves me some coffee.  The flavor was also centered around heavy coffee maltage, and picked up a lovely complement of drier dark chocolate.. the edges showcased fresh coffee bitterness, fresh oak, vanilla, and light bourbon sugars.. everything came together perfectly.. long, drawn-out coffee finish with a little more of that vanilla.  Medium-plus bodied with moderate coffee bitterness throughout.. it doesnt seem like this was in the barrel for long, but the light bourbon impression worked well.  This was excellent!

Dark color.  Smell of heavy roasted coffee and some minor bourbon.  Taste of sweet roasted coffee, pine, malt, hops, vanilla, oak and bourbon.  Not a overpowering bourbon taste.  Just a enough to make it a very nice BB porter.  The coffee dominated the smell and taste of this brew.

Pours a thick dark brown color with a nice tan head. Gigantic aroma of coffee punched me in the nose upon first wiff. Not much else making it through that great coffee bean aroma. Flavor is of coffee bean that is perfectly intertwined with hints of vanilla and bourbon. Great, smooth as silk body as well. Leaves a great coffee aftertaste in your mouth.Wow....what a excellent brew! Thanks Brewblackhole!

Fresh coffee laden aroma,roasted beans coming through big time,just the tiniest pecks on the nostrils of the bourbon, smells much richer then the first batch,as it warms a little more bourbon vanilla and sweetness comes through, taste is two lumps of sugar coffee at first,silky smooth and creamy to the palate. Roasted malts and that creamy slightly sweet coffee wash around the palate,and then and only then in the swallow ,the smooth traces of bourbon finishes it off. This brew retains all the wonderful coffee aspects we loved in the in the first brew,the sexy oatmeal smoothness,and adds that tantalizing bourbon finish in the swallow. This beer almost makes me wish I were smoking again. I can so see me sitting in a beatnilk coffee house listening to Tom Waits,drinking a couple of these,with a pack of cigs by me. One of the top new brews of the year
